autoIP’s API Reference

autoIP implements the general procedure for solving Bayesian Inverse Problems such that the end result is autodifferentiable.

Time Independent Inverse problems

class autoip.TIIP.TIIP(P_prior, P_obs, F, y)[source]

Bases: Mapping

Dataclass representing a Time Independent Inverse Problem.

Parameters

  • P_prior (Gaussian) – The prior distribution.

  • P_obs (Gaussian) – The observation distribution.

  • F (Operator) – The parameter-to-observable map.

  • y (Array) – The observation.

P_prior: Gaussian
P_obs: Gaussian
F: Operator
y: Array
from_tuple()
replace(**kwargs)
to_tuple()
autoip.TIIP.linear_Hessian(ip, x)[source]

Compute the Hessian action of the cost functional for a linear parameter-to-observable map.

This is given by the expression

\[H(x) = F^T \Sigma_{\rm obs}^{-1} F(x) + \Sigma_{\rm prior}^{-1} x\]

where \(\Sigma_{\rm obs}\) and \(\Sigma_{\rm prior}\) are the covariance matrices of the observation and prior distributions respectively, \(F\) is the linear parameter-to-observable map.

Parameters

  • ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

  • x (ArrayLike) – Point to act on.

Returns

The Hessian action at the given point.

Return type

Array

autoip.TIIP.linear_MAP(ip, **kwargs)[source]

Compute the maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate for a linear inverse problem.

This is given by the closed form expression

\[\hat{x} = H^{-1} \left( F^T \Sigma_{\rm obs}^{-1} y + \Sigma_{\rm prior}^{-1} \mu_{\rm prior} \right)\]

where \(\mathcal{H}\) is the Hessian of the cost functional \(J\), \(\Sigma_{\rm obs}\) and \(\Sigma_{\rm prior}\) are the covariance matrices of the observation and prior distributions respectively, \(\mu_{\rm prior}\) is the mean of the prior distribution, and \(F\) is the linear parameter-to-observable map,

Internally, this function uses a conjugate gradient solver to solve the linear system \(H \hat{x} = b\) where \(b = F^T \Sigma_{\rm obs}^{-1} y + \Sigma_{\rm prior}^{-1} \mu_{\rm prior}\), as we’re guaranteed that the Hessian is symmetric positive definite in this case. Practically, this is implemented using Jax’s jax.scipy.sparse.linalg.cg() function which, by default, impmements derivatives via implicit differentiation as opposed to differentiating through the linear solver.

Parameters

ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

Keyword Arguments

**kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to jax.scipy.sparse.linalg.cg().

Returns

The MAP estimate.

Return type

Array

autoip.TIIP.assemble_linear_posterior(ip, **kwargs)[source]

Assemble the posterior distribution for a linear inverse problem.

This is glue code that assembles the posterior distribution for a linear inverse problem from the MAP estimate and by explicitly computing the posterior covariance and its Cholesky factorization from the linear Hessian of the cost functional, i.e. \(\Sigma_{\rm post} = H^{-1}\).

Warning

Constructing the posterior distribution in this way is not recommended for even medium sized problems, as it involes \(N\) Hessian solves for \(H \in \mathbb{R}^{N \times N}\).

Parameters

ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

Keyword Arguments

**kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to jax.scipy.sparse.linalg.cg() for both the MAP estimate and in the construction of the posterior covariance from linear Hessian solves.

Return type

Gaussian

autoip.TIIP.IPCost(ip, theta)[source]

Compute the cost functional for an inverse problem.

This is given by the expression

\[\hat{C}(\theta) = -\log \hat{p}(y | F(\theta)) - \log \hat{p}(\theta)\]

where \(\hat{p}(y | F(\theta))\) is the unnormalized likelihood of the observation given the parameter-to-observable map evaluated at \(\theta\) and \(\hat{p}(\theta)\) is the unnormalized prior distribution.

Parameters

  • ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

  • theta (ArrayLike) – The point at which to evaluate the cost functional.

Return type

float

autoip.TIIP.gradIPCost(ip, theta)[source]

Compute the gradient of the cost functional for an inverse problem.

This is given by the expression

\[\nabla \hat{C}(\theta) = J^T \Sigma_{\rm obs}^{-1} \left( F(\theta) - y \right) + \Sigma_{\rm prior}^{-1} \left( \theta - \mu_{\rm prior} \right)\]

where \(\Sigma_{\rm obs}\) and \(\Sigma_{\rm prior}\) are the covariance matrices of the observation and prior distributions respectively, \(F\) is the parameter-to-observable map, \(J\) is the Jacobian of the parameter-to-observable map and particularily \(J^T\) is the adjoint of the parameter-to-observable map, \(y\) is the observation, and \(\mu_{\rm prior}\) is the mean of the prior distribution.

Parameters

  • ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

  • theta (ArrayLike) – The point at which to evaluate the gradient of the cost functional.

autoip.TIIP.nonlinear_MAP(ip)[source]

Compute the maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate for a nonlinear inverse problem.

This is given by solving the optimization problem

\[\hat{\theta} = \arg\min_{\theta} \hat{C}(\theta)\]

where \(\hat{C}(\theta)\) is the cost functional for the inverse problem. This is done using Jax’s jaxopt.LBFGS() function.

Parameters

ip (TIIP) – The inverse problem represented by a TIIP dataclass.

Returns

Returns (params, state) where params is the MAP estimate and state is the state of the optimizer.

Gaussian Distribution Utilities

class autoip.gaussian.Gaussian(mean, cov, L)[source]

Bases: Mapping

Dataclass representing a Gaussian distribution.

In addition to the mean and covariance, the Cholesky factorization of the covariance is also stored, i.e. \(\Sigma = LL^T\). This is done for reasons of performance. It must be the case that \(LL^T \approx \Sigma\) and that \(L\) is lower triangular.

Parameters

  • mean (Array) – The mean of the Gaussian distribution.

  • cov (Array) – The covariance of the Gaussian distribution.

  • L (Array) – The Cholesky factorization of the covariance.

autoip.gaussian.precision_action(G, x)[source]

Compute the action of the precision matrix (covariance inverse) of the given Gaussian distribution on a point.

As each Gaussian is assumed to have an accompanying Cholesky factor, this action is computed using a Cholesky accelerated triangular solve via the Jax function jax.scipy.linalg.cho_solve().

Parameters

  • G (Gaussian) – The Gaussian distribution.

  • x (ArrayLike) – The point at which to evaluate the precision action.

Return type

Array

autoip.gaussian.sample(G, key)[source]

Sample from the given Gaussian distribution.

This is given by the formula \(\mu + L\epsilon\) where \(\epsilon \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I)\).

Parameters

  • G (Gaussian) – The Gaussian to sample from.

  • key (PRNGKey) – The PRNG key to use for sampling.

Return type

Array

autoip.gaussian.logpdf(G, x, normalized=False)[source]

Compute the log-probability of the given Gaussian distribution at a point.

This is given by the expression

\[\log p(x) = -\frac{1}{2} (x - \mu)^T \Sigma^{-1} (x - \mu) - \frac{k}{2} \log (2\pi |\Sigma|)\]
Parameters

  • G (Gaussian) – The Gaussian distribution.

  • x (ArrayLike) – The point at which to evaluate.

  • normalized – Whether to return the normalized log-probability.

Return type

float

autoip.gaussian.kl_divergence(G1, G2)[source]

Compute the KL divergence between two Gaussian distributions.

This is given by the expression

\[D_{\rm KL}(\mathcal{N}(\mu_1, \Sigma_1) || \mathcal{N}(\mu_2, \Sigma_2)) = \frac{1}{2} \left( \log \frac{|\Sigma_2|}{|\Sigma_1|} - k + \mathrm{tr}(\Sigma_2^{-1} \Sigma_1) + ||\mu_2 - \mu_1||^2_{\Sigma_2^{-1}} \right)\]
Parameters

  • G1 (Gaussian) – The first Gaussian distribution.

  • G2 (Gaussian) – The second Gaussian distribution.

Return type

float
